Notes: 1-point test, failed, device similar to HT-I Sequoia.
1-point test, repeat f Otero, also failed.
154 pounds (70 kg) test device successful.
1-point test, repeat of Otero/Bernalillo, still unsafe.
1-point test, declared success despite yield, XW-42 test, similar to Pascal-C and San Juan devices.
1-point test, declared success despite yield, similar to Pascal-C and San Juan devices.
1-point test, similar to Tamalpais and Ceres.
Full yield test of device similar to Otero et al., fizzled.
1-point test of 'Moccasin, failed, similar to Coulomb-C.
1-point test of device similar to Otero et al., failed.  Unstemmed shaft.
Full yield test, similar to Mars and Ceres.
Concept feasibility test, similar to HT-I Linden.
Full yield test of device similar to Otero et al., fizzled.
1-point test, failed, similar to HT-I Hickory and HT-II Titania. First NTS subsidence crater at Rainier despite low yield and depth buried.
Davy Crockett prototype test, fizzled, extremely small device (16 kg (35 lb)).
ABM warhead test, small (28.6 kg (63 lb), 28 cm × 29 cm (11 in × 11 in)) kiloton-range device, successful.
Low yield test, similar to Otero et al.
1-point test, failed, similar to Wrangell, Oberon, Sanford.
Low yield Mk-7, successful, fired on wooden tower.
1-point test, successful, safe design extrapolated from Pascal-C and HT-II Valencia. Unstemmed shaft.
Full yield test of XW-54 primary, successful, similar to Otero et al.
Full yield test fizzle, similar to Vesta, Oberon, Sanford.
1-point test, successful, similar to Vesta, Wrangell, Sanford.
Low yield test, fizzled, similar to Mercury, Neptune, Titania.
1-point test, similar to Mora, failed, fired on wooden tower.
1-point test to determine safety limits.
1-point test of atomic artillery shell, similar to Tamalpais and Mars.
Full yield test, successful, similar to Vesta, Oberon, Wrangell.
Full yield test, disappointing yield, similar to Catron and Mora.
1-point test of device similar to De Baca, failed, fired on wooden tower.
Full yield test fizzle, similar to Blanca.
Fizzle.
Repeat of Hamilton with higher yield, extremely small device (16 kg).
Test planned for Hardtack II, but held up by atmospherics that would have shattered windows in Las Vegas, and could not be completed in time before start of moratorium negotiations.
Similar to devices fired in many preceding shots, yield below predictions.
1-point test of W-45/Swan variant, successful.
Test of alternate W-47 primary in TN mockup, successful, similar to Evans, shot vented to atmosphere through the side of the mesa.
1-point test of original XW-47 primary, declared safe despite yield, similar to HT-I Hickory and HT-II Neptune.

ReferencesNotes: [1][8][10][11][12]ABM development - part of Operation Newsreel (high-altitude tests). Fired "about 85 nmi (157 km; 98 mi) northwest of Bikini".

Elevation + height [note 4]: 1 m (3 ft 3 in) + 1 m (3 ft 3 in)
ReferencesNotes: [1][8][10][11][12] LASL test of a MK-43 primary in a thermonuclear system mockup.  Similar to Elder. 596 ft (182 m) crater southwest of the Redwing Lacrosse crater; crater later became the Cactus Dome.
[1][8][10][12] Clean 2-stage TN device, only 90 kt fission, 93.4% fusion yield.
[1][8][10][12] TX-46 primary test, similar to Oak and Yellowwood.

Elevation + height [note 4]: 2 m (6 ft 7 in) + 0.81 m (2 ft 8 in)
ReferencesNotes: [1][8][10][12] XW-35 ICBM warhead test.
[1][8][10][12] Mk-7 deep underwater explosion effects, water depth 3,200 ft (980 m).
[1][8][10][12] XW-31Y proof test.
[1][8][10][12] 2 stage thermonuclear device, possible W47.
[1][8][10][11][12] LASL developmental test of a "clean" TX-46 warhead design. Fizzled, low burn in secondary. Retry in Oak.
[1][8][10][12] Exploratory shot, XW-50 Nike-Zeus prototype, 2nd stage failed to ignite.
[1][8][10][12]"Clean" TX-41 fizzle; predicted yield 5 Mt total, 200 kt fission; low level burning in 2nd stage; similar to Poplar and Pine.
[1][8][10][12] Exploratory shot, possible XW-49, 80 kt fusion expected, 2nd stage failed to ignite.
[1][8][10][11][12] Shallow underwater explosion on lagoon bottom at 150 ft (46 m). Crater 915 m × 6 m (3,002 ft × 20 ft).
[1][8][10][12]"Dirty" 2-stage test, predicted to be 89% fission.
[1][8][10][12] Possible XW-47 prototype, 2 stage.
[1][8][10][12] Thermonuclear prototype development test.
[1][8][10][12] Possible XW-50 primary.
[1][8][10][12] Possible XW-47 prototype, 2-stage, 250 kt fission yield expected; similar to Aspen, Nutmeg, Dogwood devices.
[1][8][10][12] TX-43 laydown bomb test, 50% fission yield expected, similar to Cactus.
[1][8][10][11][12] Prototype test of the LASL designed TX-46 system. Similar to Butternut and Yellowwood. Crater 1,750 m × 80 m (5,740 ft × 260 ft).
[1][8][10][12] Possible XW-47 primary test, similar to Hardtack II Neptune and Titania.
[1][8][10][12] Similar to Hardtack II Otero, test of Hardtack I Pisonia primary.
[1][8][10][12] 2-stage "clean" thermonuke device, predicted fission yield 30 kt.
[1][8][10][12] Similar to Redwood, Aspen, Nutmeg; possible XW-47 prototype, Piccolo 2nd stage.
[1][8][10][12] TX-41 "clean" 2-stage variant; similar to Pine and Sycamore; largest of Hardtack I, and 5th largest U.S. test ever.
[1][8][10][12][13] XW-34 1-point safety test, successful.
[1][8][10][12][13] Probable prototype XW-50 thermonuclear design, modified Tobacco device, used Sequoia primary.
[1][8][10][11][12]"Most radical UCRL shot", "entirely new concept", last Bikini atmospheric shot, probable XW-47 candidate.
[1][8][10][12] Concept feasibility test, 2-stage thermonuclear device, established high yield/light weight; weight 100 kg (220 lb)  (yield/weight ratio 2 kt/kg).
[1][8][10][12] TX-41 "clean" 3-stage variant; similar to Poplar and Sycamore.
A proposed international demonstration of a clean thermonuke.  Cancelled by President Eisenhower in the runup to the 1958 test moratorium.

A test of the Spartan ABM warhead.  The largest underground nuclear test ever.

Notes: Picture of the "Ship of the Desert", a structure for capturing neutrons for experiments with this test: File:NNSA-NSO-1347.jpg.
Verification test, similar to Aztec, Kingfish, Bluegill Triple Prime. Used in a Mk-39 Mod-1 Type 3 drop case.
similar to Adobe, Kingfish, Bluegill Triple Prime, yield slightly lower than expected; achieved 2.21 kt/kg.
Highly successful; parachute retarded, only 600 ft (180 m) from aimpoint.  4.00 kt/kg.
Similar to Alma, Rinconada, Sunset, yield considerably lower than expected.

Notes: Only US operational ballistic missile launch w/live warhead, Polaris A2 SLBM launched from USS Ethan Allen, successfully detonated 2,200 yd (2,000 m) from target.
1st test of high fusion/low fission family; similar to Muskegon, Chetco, Nougat Arikaree, Hudson, Codsaw, Hoosic; yield slightly higher than expected.
Advanced primary and secondary concepts test, yield considerably lower than expected.
Advanced lightweight low fission concept, similar to Chetco and Yukon, slightly lower than expected yield.
Full scale RUR-5 ASROC ASW rocket proof test, similar to Nougat Chena, fired from USS Agerholm at target 4,348 yd (3,976 m) away.
Verification of reduced yield variant of HT-I Elder shot.
Clean" ABM warhead test, similar to Bluestone, possible W-65 progenitor, highly experimental, yield lower than expected.
Advanced light weight concept, similar to Muskegon and Yukon, yield close to predicted, only 200 ft (61 m) from target.
Fizzle with secondary fail, "radical" design.
Unique" design, advanced concepts test, yield lower than expected.
Similar to Questa, Rinconada, Sunset. 3.12 kt/kg.
Development and verification test for the Polaris A-3 weapon (3 MIRV), satisfactory.
Advanced concepts test, similar to HT-I Koa, performed as expected.
Successful, doubled W-47Y1 yield, 3.42 kt/kg.
Increased yield warhead test, successful, similar to Questa, Alma, Sunset.  3.48 kt/kg.
Experimental lightweight, high efficiency design, similar to Mesilla, basic design adequacy confirmed.
Advanced concepts test, second LRL fizzle, no secondary.
Advanced concepts test of "novel system".
Advanced concepts test, successful.  4.14 kt/kg.
Similar to Swanee; 4.96 kt/kg.
High yield advanced concepts test, similar to Questa, Alma, Rinconada, 4.06 kt/kg.
Advanced principles test for high-efficiency fusion burn, successful, last Christmas Island airdrop; 0.934 kt/kg (experimental drops are low usually).

Notes: Possible Ripple device, fizzle, retested in Housatonic shot.

Notes: Retest of Petit, yield much lower than expected, test to improve yield-to-weight ratio.

Notes: Test of lightweight small diameter device, possible replacement for W-38, yield below predicted value.

Notes: Third drop test of specific device to maximize yield to weight ratio.

Notes: Repeat of Androscoggin, successful, target accuracy within 100 ft (30 m); last U.S. nuclear weapon airdrop.  2.56 kt/kg.
XW-40 lightweight boosted fission warhead test.
XW-30 warhead test, fizzled. Retested successfully with Franklin Prime, with more fissile in the core and different explosives.
Fizzle, unboosted all-oralloy small weapon design.
XW-45X1 Swan test, gas-boosted composite pit.
Effects shot with OTS weapon. Similar to that tested in Redwing Lacrosse.
Safety experiment, successful.
Largest atmospheric test in CONUS. Was a 2-stage thermonuclear device, even though AEC stated that no thermonuclear devices were being tested at the NTS. Desert Rock VII.
Very similar to the Shasta test device. 2 stage. Misfired at first firing attempt three days earlier.
Proof test of AIR-2A Genie air-to-air rocket. Test made famous by five USAF officers and a videographer standing at ground zero below the hypocentre and during the detonation, flash and blast.
ICBM warhead, similar to Hardtack I/Koa.
Very small boosted plutonium device, XW-51 progenitor.
Originally Galileo A. One-point safety experiment, failure. Expected yield was less than 1 kg. A concrete cylinder perhaps 2 m (6 ft 7 in) thick 100 m (330 ft) up the tube disappeared.
Tactical Atomic Demolition Munition (TADM) and Talos SAM warhead.
One-point safety experiment; first shot in a Rainier tunnel.
2 stage thermonuclear design.
LASL gas boosted implosion device, possible XW-34 test.

Shaft safety experiment, failed. Sent a 4 in (100 mm) thick steel cap weighing several hundred pounds possibly into solar orbit or burn up in atmosphere, estimated velocity more than 66 km/s (41 mi/s).
Retest of Franklin with more U-235.
2 stages of 3 stage thermonuke, similar to Redwing/Zuni and Tewa. Desert Rock VII; 3000 servicemen irradiated; 10 of 4 expected leukemia cases in the 80s. Last pristine air-drop location at the NTS.
LASL diagnostic/exploratory test of boosted fission device. Desert Rock VIII.
Retest of redesigned Lassen device, possible XW-51 air-to-air warhead progenitor.
One-point safety experiment, high limits test, expected 1 kg TNT equivalent, max .2 kt - failure.
The third of only four gun-type weapons, with Little Boy, Grable and Aardvark. The XW-33 was a gun shell.
LASL boosted fission device. Possibly a test of the XW-34 depth bomb.
LASL test of XW-31 variant, boosted primary in thermonuclear system mockup. Sounds like a fizzle, but no one says so.

First US underground nuclear test. Evaluate containment and detection of underground testing, formed a chimney of broken rock which provided data on possible underground engineering applications of nuclear explosives.
Test of boosted Swan primary in W-27 thermonuclear system mockup.
UCRL test of a small "clean" tactical 2-stage thermonuclear device. Device fizzled when second stage failed to fire.

Test of a new line-of-sight pipe configuration for tunnel testing, basic measurements of blast parameters. The configuration proved to be inadequate for effects testing of warheads.

Simultaneous, same hole.
Shot to test the MX missile shallow buried trench basing concept to see if a nearby nuclear fireball would cause the trench to act as a shock tube.
Fizzle? Device destroyed by Quicksilver/Hearts detonation on 1979.

Became stuck in shaft while being lowered; abandoned, later destroyed by Tinderbox/Azul.
See Whetstone/Cambric.  A test of groundwater mobility in moving buried radiaoactives, this time in volcanic rock/soil.

Mockup of the TX-39.  Left a visible Crater off Runit Island, next to Cactus Dome, 600 ft (180 m) in diameter.

The United States' first air deliverable thermonuclear device. Navigation error landed weapon 4 mi (6.4 km) off aim point (Namu), negated effects data gathering and placing unprotected military personnel facing the blast they had been arranged to have their backs to. The air force identified the test technician that disclosed the miss as Airman First Class Jackson H. Kilgore, for which he was reprimanded. Effects test, but also an international political statement about readiness to drop thermonuclear weapons.
First test of 3 stage device.  Clean version using lead tamper, 85% fusion; Tewa is dirty version of same bomb. Design evolved into Mk-41, largest deployed US bomb.
Smallest (5 in (130 mm) diameter), lightest (96 lb (44 kg)) air defense warhead to date, a boosted, asymmetrical linear implosion device. Fizzled when boost didn't work.
Test of boosted primary for TX-28C (for "clean") thermonuke.

Elevation + height [note 4]: 2 m (6 ft 7 in) + 2 m (6 ft 7 in)
Notes: Exploded in a water tank to simulate underground nuke test. Left crater 660 ft × 32 ft (201.2 m × 9.8 m).
Small air defense prototype.  A near-minimal diameter spherical implosion system, 11.5 in (290 mm) in diameter.
TX-28S (for "salted") test, intentionally dirty  high fallout, 73% fission.
Linear implosion, air defense warhead test.
Proof test of XW-25.
Test of tactical warhead, evolved into XW-45.
Prototype of XW-28C.  Became the most versatile, widely used design in the US, from 1958 to 1990.
Same primary as Lacrosse; Prototype of XW-27 warhead for Regulus missile.
95% fusion, cleanest shot fired until 1958.
87% fission; first US 3 stage device, dirty version of Bassoon tested in Zuni, with tamper change. Developed into Mk-41.
2 Stage thermonuke, XW-50 prototype.

Notes: Destroyed Cresset/Transom device which didn't detonate.

14 injured, 1 died in unexpected crater collapse following test; the only fatality from testing at NTS. Unlike other tunnel tests, Milagro required high speed video links, so a data trailer park was built above it.

Stockpile confidence test, partial-yield test of an aging W56[9]
Air defense test. Light weight implosion system, 120 lb (54 kg) and 22 in (560 mm) across. Desert Rock VI.
Proof test of XW30 air defense warhead. Used an ENS (external neutron source) initiator. Desert Rock VI.
First successful UCRL test; used linear implosion, ZIPPER initiator. Desert Rock VI.
Test of primary for XW-27 class D, lightweight thermonuke, in an XW-27 mockup. Desert Rock VI.
Boosted XW-30. A sealed pit D-T gas boost design, with ZIPPER initiator.
LASL sealed pit D-T gas boosted design, with ZIPPER initiator. Desert Rock VI.
Effects Sub-surface". Test for ADM (Atomic Demolition Munition). Desert Rock VI.
Primary failed; expected 40 kt. Desert Rock VI.
Repeat of Wasp. Desert Rock VI.
High altitude" test of air-air missile warhead similar to Wasp Prime; parachute retarded (only one at NTS).
LLNL Linear implosion. ENS initiated.
Military Effects Tower". Supposed to be a standard effects test, LASL clandestinely substituted experimental U233/Pu core, thus undershot estimated yield by a third. Desert Rock VI.
Retry of Apple-1. Desert Rock VI. Operation Cue, civil defense exercise.
Test of Class D primary/secondary system.
Destroyed the Anvil/Peninsula device that was damaged during placement.

Radiation and EMP effects shot through a mockup DSCS satellite on the surface, which was then towed off the collapsing cap.  Picture of the test chamber.  It is still on the NE lip of the test's crater.

Fallout [note 9]: Venting detected off site, 2.2 kCi (81 TBq)

Notes: Simultaneous, separate holes.
Simultaneous, separate holes.
The American part of the Joint Verification Experiment.
Simultaneous, separate holes.
Simultaneous, separate holes.
Investigated yield-vs-initiation time curve. Live news coverage. Desert Rock V. Two 2-story houses, 50 autos, bomb shelters in effects test.
Component test of TX-14[2]:193, 195 containing minimal quantities of Li-6D.[2]:170 Desert Rock V. First proof-test of the RACER boosted primary with disappointing performance.[Note 1]

1st UCRL device, a uranium deuteride core,[2]:202 meant to explore deuterated polyethylene mixed with uranium as thermonuclear fuel,[10]:chap.15[2]:203 and if successful to lead also to a compact thermonuclear primary.[2]:149 Predicted yield was 1.5 to 3 kilotons, max. theoretical was 20 kt.[9]:96 Device fizzled - deuterium moderated (slowed-down) neutrons more than expected and quenched the reaction. Embarrassing for designers, as it left 200 ft (61 m) of tower still standing (see image of tower).

TX-5D proof test, a boosting experiment using lithium deuteride in solid or crystalline form, investigating initiation via deuterium; a cheap method to initiate a chain reaction.[2]:185 Exploded 600 ft (180 m) ENE of intended zero point.

2nd UCRL device, uranium deuteride[2]:202 meant to explore deuterated polyethylene mixed with uranium as thermonuclear fuel,[10]:chap.15[2]:203 and if successful to lead also to a compact thermonuclear primary;[2]:149 Used different mix from Ruth[2]:202 and it also fizzled. Legend has it that 100 foot tower was used, to avoid embarrassment in case of fizzle.
Component test of the TX-16 using a cryogenic mockup secondary and the TX-16 radiation case. Also tested RACER primary, which performed below expectations again. Desert Rock V.

Component test of TX-17/24 series using the RACER IV primary, a modified RACER core containing two additional kilograms of HEU in the original design tested in Nancy, a thermonuclear secondary mockup.[5]
Effects" test. Dropped 950 ft (290 m) SSW of target. Desert Rock V, bad exposures for troops and bad downwinder fallout.

New hollow core design, most efficient pure-plutonium device under 100 kt indicates very good compression. Major effects testing of a high elevation explosion. Heaviest downwind contamination measured.

The 2nd of four gun-type device tests. Fired from Annie M65 Atomic Cannon 11 km (6.8 mi) downrange. 280mm shell, 365 kg (805 lb). Detonation at 200 feet (61 m) SW of target. Desert Rock V. Major effects test.

Proof test of a boosted MK-7 device, intended to be used as a primary in Castle. Initially it was intended only for the TX-15[2]:195. After RACER's inconsistent behaviour it was opted for all "emergency capability" devices instead.[2]:197. The bomb detonated 320 ft (98 m) NW of target. Composite implosion system in a Type D pit. Used Cyclotol 75/25 explosive mixture.

Notes: Third try for Bluegill; booster failure at 86 seconds and rocket started tumbling, RSO destroyed rocket at 156 seconds. Some debris rained on Johnston Island.

Location [note 3]: Launch from Johnston Island, Johnston Atoll 16°44′01″N 169°31′31″W﻿ / ﻿16.73365°N 169.52534°W, elv: 3 + 0 m (9.8 + 0.0 ft);Detonation over Johnston Island, Johnston Atoll 16°04′21″N 169°36′36″W﻿ / ﻿16.07239°N 169.60997°W
Notes: High altitude effects shot, XM-33 Strypi rocket with Recruit booster.

Local time zone [note 2][26]: jamt (-11 hrs)Believed in use during Dominic, Fishbowl, HT I.[27]
Location [note 3]: Launch from Johnston Island, Johnston Atoll 16°44′01″N 169°31′31″W﻿ / ﻿16.73365°N 169.52534°W, elv: 3 + 0 m (9.8 + 0.0 ft);Detonation over Johnston Island, Johnston Atoll 16°24′57″N 169°36′11″W﻿ / ﻿16.41583°N 169.60311°W
Notes: 4th attempt.  Thor missile launched successfully, similar to Adobe, Aztec, Kingfish.  Little EMP recorded. Two military suffered eye injuries.

Local time zone [note 2][26]: jamt (-11 hrs)Believed in use during Dominic, Fishbowl, HT I.[27]
Location [note 3]: Launch from Johnston Island, Johnston Atoll 16°44′01″N 169°31′31″W﻿ / ﻿16.73365°N 169.52534°W, elv: 3 + 0 m (9.8 + 0.0 ft);Detonation over Johnston Island, Johnston Atoll 16°06′49″N 169°40′56″W﻿ / ﻿16.1135°N 169.68222°W
Notes: Thor missile launched, similar to Adobe, Aztec, Bluegill Triple Prime.  Viewed all over central Pacific, 3 hours ionospheric interference.

Local time zone [note 2][26]: jamt (-11 hrs)Believed in use during Dominic, Fishbowl, HT I.[27]
Location [note 3]: Launch from Johnston Island, Johnston Atoll 16°44′01″N 169°31′31″W﻿ / ﻿16.73365°N 169.52534°W, elv: 3 + 0 m (9.8 + 0.0 ft);Detonation over Johnston Island, Johnston Atoll 16°42′27″N 169°32′33″W﻿ / ﻿16.70742°N 169.54242°W
Notes: Air defense warhead on Nike Hercules missile, last U.S. atmospheric test, test of missile defense system, successful. Last true US "atmospheric" test before PTBT.
U-235 core, same as Ranger/Able.
Proof test of new core (?). First blast broadcast live on TV. Desert Rock IV.
Tested deuterium (without tritium) gas fusion boosting. Investigate rope trick. Desert Rock IV.
First use of beryllium as tamper.
Designed to test the initiation/yield curve. Calibration test for TOM polonium/beryllium internal initiator. Desert Rock IV.
Tested an external betatron initiator that shot x-rays into the core, which induced neutrons by photofission.  Desert Rock IV.
First test to use a beryllium neutron reflector/tamper.
Minimum mass design, fizzle (yield "less than a pound"); yet it yielded a lower bound on viable plutonium mass. October 19 attempt failed due to control wiring problem.
No uranium tamper.
Desert Rock I, no fallout (air burst).  Troops trucked into defensive emplacements from 6 mi (9.7 km) observation point, held maneuvers.
Surface" shot, only true surface shot in NTS history. Desert Rock II; maneuvers conducted at a distance due to dirtiness.
Cratering shot, meant to simulate 23 kt ground penetrating weapon. Desert Rock III, observed at 5 mi (8.0 km), kept distance in maneuvers.  5000 R/Hr near GZ  one hour after shot.
Simultaneous, same drifts.
Simultaneous, same drifts.
Simultaneous, same drifts.
Treaty verification test.
Treaty verification test.
Simultaneous, same hole.
Simultaneous, same hole.
Simultaneous, same hole.
Last U.S. nuclear test; "test to ensure safety of deterrent forces".

Elevation + height [note 4]: 2 m (6 ft 7 in) + 2 m (6 ft 7 in)
Notes: Used a RACER IV primary. Over twice as powerful as predicted, error in assessing Li-7.  Lethal fallout, killed radioman on Japanese vessel Daigo Fukuryu Maru (Fifth Lucky Dragon); 1 fatality, 93+ injured. Design used in Mk-21/36. Largest US atmospheric detonation.
Exceeded yield expectations, by almost a factor of 3. Proof test of the Mk-17, deployed as the EC-17.
Scheduled for Castle but not executed, location and time are as planned. It cancelled when the Bravo test was so unexpectedly successful, making cryogenic thermonuclear concepts obsolete.

Elevation + height [note 4]: 2 m (6 ft 7 in) + 1 m (3 ft 3 in)
Notes: UCRL design, last one that Teller worked on, secondary delayed too long, and fizzled at 110 kt yield.
Prototype EC-14, used expensive 95% enriched Li-6 fuel, RACER IV primary.
Proof test of TX/EC-24 with a RACER IV primary. After Bravo's success, the wet/dry TX/EC-16 Jughead device that was to be tested was discarded for the Runt2 dry device, hence the "2" designation.
Test of stage 3 fission from fast neutrons.

First test over continental United States since Trinity. Testing compression against critical mass as inspired by the demon core.  Often later used for a 1 kt calibrated explosion. See also Ranger/Easy.
Fractional critical core, TOM initiator. See also Ranger/Easy.
Testing compression against critical mass.
Identical to Baker-1, test of reproducible results. See also Ranger/Easy.
Proof Test of Mark 6 HOW  "Fox" core. "500 ft west and 300 ft south of drop target used by other Ranger blasts, to avoid damage to the control point.".
Proof test of Mark 6, 60 point implosion. Hansen says "north end of Runit".

Proof test of Mark 5, 92 point lense implosion system, used as the primary for Ivy Mike.  Mock buildings (homes, bunkers, factories) were assembled on Enjebi and Mujinkarikku Island. Hansen: "west end of Engebi".
Deuterium core,  proof test of staged thermonuclear design, but most yield from boosted fission.
First tritium boosted test.

One point safety test of sealed pit, successful.  Extra oralloy in the core and three zippers were used to make sure of a worst case condition in the pit for supporting fission, which would have been deemed a test failure.
One point safety test of W-25 sealed pit, successful. 3 zippers used to make sure of plentiful neutrons.
One point safety test of TX/W-28 primary, successful. 3 zippers used to make sure of plentiful neutrons.
One point safety test partial failure, due to large neutron initiation (6 zippers) in what would otherwise have been a just-barely-critical device.
One point safety test, partially successful (?).
One point safety test, upper bound overtest. Similar to the Moccasin device fired in Hardtack II Hidalgo. Failure, 500 ton explosion.
One point safety test, partially successful (?). Similar to Hardtack II Oberon and Sanford devices.
One point safety test, partially successful (?). Similar to devices fired in Hardtack II Mars, Tamalpais, and Ceres.
Used a stockpile Davy Crockett warhead.  The Army's part of Sunbeam was Operation Ivy Flats.
TADM (Tactical Atomic Demolition Munition) test, similar to Plumbbob Stokes.
Test of missile silo hardening principles, specifically EMP,  similar to Nougat Ermine, Chinchilla I/II, Armadillo.

Fallout [note 9]: Venting detected off site, 3 kCi (110 TBq)
Notes: Army Operation Ivy Flats, witnessed by Robert Kennedy. Last atmospheric test at NTS, used a stockpile Davy Crockett warhead.
Storage-transportation safety experiment, measured plutonium dispersal risk.
Storage-transportation safety experiment, measured plutonium dispersal risk.
Storage-transportation safety experiment, measured plutonium dispersal risk.
Storage-transportation safety experiment, measured plutonium dispersal risk.
2:1 oralloy-plutonium, levitated core.  2.38 kg (5.2 lb) Pu + 4.77 kg (10.5 lb) oralloy yielded 37 kt at 21% efficiency.  Levitation was considered a top secret technique until 1980.
Oralloy core 2.5 kg (5.5 lb) Pu, 5 kg (11 lb) U235. (Hanson says it probably was pure U-235), levitated core.
Considered so optimal that it was put into immediate production for Mark 4.
Megaton ("M" as in Mike) device. First true experimental H-bomb, used cryogenic deuterium; became TX-16 weapon. Elugelab completely cratered.
Kiloton ("K" as in King) device. Aka Super oralloy bomb (SOB), used 4 critical masses of U235.  Largest pure fission device; also tested chain safety device.
Deep water submarine hull test, including nuclear depth bomb, to gauge surface contamination. Used instrumented "squaws", subscale sub pressure hulls. Tested shielded warships with base surge.
Contamination hazard test of the XW-25 air defense warhead; successful.
Simultaneous, separate holes.
Simultaneous, separate holes.
